feed.title: Rejniak Dot Com
feed.subtitle: Exploring ideas at the intersection of data science and revenue operations & enablement. Also space for personal obervations & rants.

entry.title: Some Writing Poject Ideas
entry.content:
I’m sharing a couple of project ideas in the vein of “accountability” as I work on getting the wiring hooked up for production.

An Operator’s Companion to The Qualified Sales Leader

John McMahon’s recent hit The Qualified Sales Leader: Proven Lessons From a Five-Time CRO codifies the seller and sales leader wisdom he developed while serving as CRO at PTC, Geo-Tel, Ariba, BladeLogic, and BMC. The book illuminates the perils and pearls of a modern day enterprise software seller, from QBR to close.

I will provide a chapter-by-chapter interpretration of The Qualified Sales Leader from an operations and enablement perspective. I’ll attempt to create an operator’s companion to help the massive operations and enablement community to align with

With 57 chapters across five parts, I’m thinking:

  • Reflect on two chapters a week (occassionally more; some chapters are a page or two)
  • Post the content on LinkedIn in hopes of generating discussion and feedback
  • Complete in about six months (in parallel with work and last term of school)
  • Edit and compile version one a month or so later

Diary of an Internet Sensation

Through the process of helping my mother navigate a family-motivated legal dispute a few years ago, I learned that one of my cousins published many, in my opinion, despicable articles about other close family members—but then I learned there were many years worth of his online and courtroom battles. I was fascinated by the bombastic writings, the different personas, the contradictions, the bravado, the inhumanity.

I’m inspired to compile, connect, and cataloge them here.

No plan here, yet. Rough ideas. This will require a lot of leg work. This will be me scratching an old journalism itch.
entry.summary: I’m sharing a couple of project ideas in the vein of “accountability” as I work on getting the wiring hooked up for production.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
